ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Many of the readings for this class are readings that you should know in order to have a solid foundation for sociology and social theory. Even if you are not a sociology major, the readings can still be valuable.
a lot of very difficult to understand theory but it's a major requirement so that makes sense

I learned about theory in detail from several of the foundational authors of sociological theory. I developed skills on how to closely read difficult texts from different time periods. I gained insight on how these texts apply to modern contexts.

This course gave me a comprehensive knowledge of the major social theorists from Hobbes Locke and Rousseau through Marx and Weber and into the late 20th century. I learned to critically evaluate how we conceive of societies, the assumptions we make about their emergence, and the methods used by people to elaborate ideas concerning how people organize themselves and each other.

I learned about foundational sociologists and their ideas. I compared and contrasted their ideas to distinguish the nuances between them. I gained confidence in discussion sections with support from my TA and the welcoming, collaborative environment.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: interesting readings, lecture outlines were very helpful, and professor was engaging
Weaknesses: grading for the papers consisted of whether or not you hit all the key points, which students were not aware of before submitting the midterm paper.

strength: very structured
weakness: not engaging at all - straight lecture with no engagement

Lectures are detailed but I wished that there were clearer expectations or guidelines for the midterm and final essays. It felt like a lot was expected in the essays and lecture notes importance was understated for the midterm paper.

The main strength of this course was how the professor had a straightforward organization and approach to his lectures which makes note taking and understanding the readings very easy to follow. I think this course could be improved with more tips on how to approach these difficult texts at the onset.

The content was amazing and I really enjoyed myself. I found that the essays and the weekly reading responses were pretty well organized
One downside of the class was that it was unclear what the essays were supposed to discuss. While we were given prompts, they were very broad and were not focused, meaning that you could feasibly write anything. However, I found that the professor expected certain arguments or comments to be made, but did not inform the class what he wanted to see, so many people ended up being conflicted between restating the course content and coming up with their own ideas about the texts we read. Multiple students I spoke with agree that a rubric explaining what we are graded on would be very helpful, because then it would be possible to answer all the professor's prompt questions fully in the way he expects while also coming up with our own interpretations and analyses.

Strengths:
- TA
- Discussion sections
- Sociologists chosen

Weaknesses:
- The lecture wasn't engaging 
- No participation time in lecture
The selections of readings were enjoyable and informative, and the lecture notes helped to fill any gaps and expand on ideas drawn out in the readings.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is not the first class that I would take if I was not a sociology major; however, I think that the readings assigned are important to read. Papers were a little stressful at times, especially the midterm paper. Overall, lectures were engaging because they served as a check of your own understanding of the readings.
no unless it is for your major
I would recommend this course to any prospective sociology majors.

I recommend this course to anyone interested in the history of ideas and the theoretical works of literature that have prefaced modern sociology and the ways we think about societies. I think it is a cool class and enjoyed the content

I would only recommend this to another student if they are a sociology major, as it gives you the necessary background and foundational ideas in the field. The weaknesses I listed above are the reasons I wouldn't recommend to other non-sociology students.
Probably not, unless you are a Sociology major there are classes with higher engagement and better structure if you'd like to learn about political/sociological theory.
